pastebin anon here again
Im working on revamping the western brewing instructions, these are meant to be for beginners and Im assuming they will at most rebrew one time
If you can test any of these and give feedback or have other comments let me know
For black tea use 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 3 minutes.
For green tea use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 70c-75c water, brew for 3 minutes
For green oolongs use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 3-4 minutes
for dark or roasted oolongs use 1.5-2.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c-100c water, brew for 4-5 minutes
for ripe puer or other fermented teas 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 5-7 minutes
for young green puer strongly consider gongfu brewing instead, 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c water, brew for 2-3 minutes
for yellow tea? 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 2-3 minutes

>>18771546
Great improvement if only for dropping the multiple steeping stuff. 99% of people aren't even aware tea can be steeped more than once, it simply isn't done except by tea nerds fascinated with the Far East. Some places like Turkey or southern US steep tea for 15+ minutes. Directions shouldn't be totally out of touch with real life culture, typical teabag/sachet suggestions, western vendors, and ISO 3103. Here's the current version for reference
https://cdn.standards.iteh.ai/samples/73224/79469b30ce154460b38ebb10af5565cf/ISO-3103-2019.pdf

Example instructions from Upton: 2.25g 6oz (177ml) 3-4 min.
Vahdam: 2g 180ml 3-5 min.

Lipton stringed teabags contain 2.25g of tea and UK square teabags contain 3.125g. PG Tips has 2.9g. ISO 3103 traditionally used 2.83g based on an old sixpence coin. This goes into a 6-10 ounce sized cup, or 140ml for ISO 3103.
Teabag packaging directions are typically 2-5 minutes. ISO 3103 is 6 minutes for black tea with milk, 3-5 minutes for other types depending on how chopped up it is.
Green tea is fine up to 80-85C and others can use off-the-boil or more precisely 86-90C is ideal. This is based on several papers I can link if you're curious, plus I tested with a thermapen. There's not a lot of nuance. Either the tea has catechins damaged by boiling water (green) or it doesn't.

Also, u guise, keep in mind it's often mixed with milk and/or sugar. Astringency is "body" which is desirable to an extent. Upscale stores unironically offer CTC and African tea. A lot of tea is created without any consideration for drinking it like a Chinaman. It's grown in other countries too.

posts.com:
just drink the tea retards

how to tea:
bag: soak bag in water for as long as you want
loose leaf western: soak leaf in water as long as you want
gong fu: soak leaf in gaiwan for as short as you want, the more you brew the longer you can soak
grandpa: soak leaf in water, and continually refill the container when you have drank between 50-80% of the water.
general tips:
teabags are generally 1 time use, but some can be steeped more than once
loose leaf tea can generally be used more than 1 time, use them until they dont taste good anymore
water temperature: start with boiling water. some teas are more delicate and will taste unnice if you brew with water that is too hot, if that is the case use water less warm than boiling.
gram to water ratio: some teas are nice with more tea, some teas are nice with less. depending on brewing method you might want more, or less. rule of thumb is short steep = more leaf, long steep = less leaf.

Alright, for the pastebin, shou puerh round two - A Better Shou
8g/300mL 360s 100c
Night and day, you just can't brew really tightly pressed tea without a rinse, this came from a very loose cake and it's extremely obvious. Really rich, thick, a lot of sweetness comes through. No real huigan, but that's kind of what you get with aged shou. It makes it very pleasantl smooth though, no real rough cereal notes or smokiness. A lot of beetroot, very earthy, somewhat mushroomy, but more gentle like button mushrooms, nothing too provacative like chanterelles or porcini. Absolutely perfect winter tea, it's great.
Some of you might be shocked by the high leaf / water ratio and long brew time, but at least try it first. Piling the tea, if it's done right, cuts all the astringency and bitterness of the tea away. You lose a lot of flavor that way, but you gain the benefit of being able to push the tea super hard and get back a lot of flavors you wouldn't reasonably be able to extract from even a well aged sheng. Shou absolutely needs to be brewed hard, that's why it exists. I feel that people are afraid to recommend a radically different brewing style, but it's a radically different tea. I have a theory that the "all shou tastes the same" crowd are brewing it like the rest of the tea they have and drinking dui wei flavored water.
Final addendum, you can't brew rock hard shou like this, it's impossible. You need to rinse it and let it sit, if you try and do a one shot ten minute brew you're brewing it at radically different lengths of times depending on how long it takes to open up. That's how you get shitty mulchy tasting hot water. The tea I brewed yesterday was simply bad, it's thin, insipid, and none of the actual character of the leaf comes through. It needs a hard rinse, to hang out for a while and open up, and then a similar high ratio heavy brew.

picrel 7.5g 150ml rolling boil 5s-90s
Nice wood aroma, also smells like the ocean air a little. Infusion 1 was bitter, wood and not much else I was able to make out. Should I have rinsed it? Infusion 2 is much smoother, light body, has a lot of background and little foreground, reminds me of instant coffee. Noticable buzz and cha qi. Infusion 3 definitely has notes of coffee and chocolate. Infusion 4 is when it starts to balance out between the bitterness, wood and coffee. Infusion 5 has a dropoff in bitterness and body but it's still coffee-like and enjoyable. Infusion 6 is back to wood/smoky to me and tastes like how most ripes do after 6 infusions. Good durability.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18771546
Ok, going to test now. Disclosure I'm using a 120ml (4oz) cup and brewing with a brew basket. I will use the same teas for both new and old, but due to it being the dead of winter I am short on supply. I don't have a roasted oolong on hand (drank the last of it a month ago) and I don't have yellow tea because who tf has yellow tea.
>Old Green, 0.5g/100ml, 80C, 2 minutes
>New Green, 2g/100ml, 70C, 3 minutes
Using an Anhui Liu An Gua Pian, 0.6g/120ml and 2.4g/120ml. Fresh leaves for both.
While brewing, the first thing I notice with the new vs the old way is that basket brewing in a cup - the new way packs the leaf to rough about the limit, just barely not peaking over the waterline in the cup. I doubt it’s a problem, but I wanted to note it.
After brewing the new method (right) turned out a more greenish-yellow, while the old (left) turned out a more subdued color. In the picture it looks almost empty, but its a noticeable pale green tint in reality.
The old is very…watery. Tastes like hot water with a hint of tea. The hotter water is drawing out some notes of the Liu An Gua Pian that is desirable. The new method is still very light, but this is also a lighter style of green tea. If requested I may do a sencha to see how it works for a stronger japanese green. The new comes forward a lot more with the nutty chinese green notes and has a floralness that the old method lacks. It doesn’t have any bitterness despite the longer brew time. I think this is clearly and objectively superior to the old way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18775163
>>18771546

>Old Green Oolong (ball), 1g/100ml, 99c, 2 minutes
>New Green Oolong, 1-2g/100 ml, 80c, 4 minutes
Since the new is a range of 1-2g, and I’m seriously on the last of my bag of oolong, I’m going to brew it at 1.7g/120ml to have enough for the old at 1.2g/120ml
First of all, the new method’s lower heat does not open up the ball oolong effectively, it was barely opening by the end of the 4 minutes, while the old method’s high heat had it opened fully by the end of the brew time. Color turned out similar, seems the old method (left) drew out some more byproduct from the leaf, as it looks slightly oily for some reason. Same bag of tea though, just some standard taiwanese oolong.
First of all, please just gong fu oolong. These both turned out very watery. The old way draws out much more of the floral notes of the oolong, and some honeysuckle and a bit of nuttiness, but overall is a pretty weak cup. Would probably shine when eating some spicy, greasy chinese food like all oolongs do though.
The new method has a bit more penetrating fruitiness, but still is a bit watered down. Kinda has this hard to describe berry note with the tiniest bit of floralness. Its amazing how much the brew actually changes things in oolong. Benefit for the new method is it cooled down to drinking temperature much faster. Its very hard to pick a winner, I genuinely think the new needs a higher brewing temperature to open up the leaf and extract more flavor, and both just need more leaf to water. I’ll edge it for the new because the flavor is more penetrating due to the longer brew time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18775167
>>18771546

>Old Raw Puerh 0.9g/100ml, 95c, 2 minutes
>New Raw Puerh 1.5-2g/100ml, 90C, 3 minutes
This one worries me, because raw puerh never turns out good western style. I know it says “young”, but the youngest I have on hand is a 2014 cake. 1g/120ml for the old, 1.8g/120ml for the new.
First thing, the new (left) is much darker, but its actually a little less aromatic.
This isn’t so horrible, but I will put that up to it being in a cup and not 9 grams in a liter teapot. The old method is flavorful, not watery but kinda light. Very very mild bitterness, its acceptable. New method as a miniscule amount of more bitterness and a sort of acidic taste the old method doesn’t have. I don’t have much to say overall, the more I drink the new the bad notes seem to come out more, while the old method kinda just tastes like a weakly brewed raw. I actually think the old is better, but please dont brew this.

Note: I forgot to take a picture of this, sorry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18775173
>>18771546

>Old Sheng Puerh, 0.9g/100ml, 99C, 2 minutes
>New Sheng Puerh, 1.5-2g/100ml, boiling, 7 minutes
>ALTERNATIVE Sheng, 3g/100ml, boiling, 6 minutes
This one is unique because we have 2 competitors for the new pastebin. I do recommend you just gong fu this as well though. Using a 2020 Ripe, 1g for old, 2.2g for new, 3.5 grams for alternative for my 120ml cup.
Writing while this is brewing, idk why you’d do this, this takes a longer time to brew than just doing gongfu. Brewing these 3 cups took about 18 minutes if you include cleaning out the old leaves from the brew basket. In the pic, it’s old (left) new (middle) alt (right). You can tell the new and alt have a similar color, although alt didn’t reach the color until I pulled out the brew basket while the new reached it while brewing. Old is super light for sheng and see through.
The old is a very light taste of the puerh, not watery, just light. It’s not actually bad, all the good notes come through and no bad notes, just a little lacking of the fullness of the body I want from puerh.
New method is tremendously better. I get a fullness I want from puerh, though its still lighter than gong fu. The good flavors come through very well, no bad flavors. Probably not a bad way to serve it to people not comfortable with a gong fu session.
Alternative is okay too, it has the texture of puerh that you’d get with gong fu, but I’m getting more of a muddiness taste and a slight bitterness not present in the others. I’m sorry anon, I think this loses to the new method : (

>Yes, I looked up prop 65. Why did this tea have it and no other tea I've seen have it?
Prop 65 sets very low thresholds for warnings and California is a huge market. It's way easier/cheaper to slap the warning on everything than to have to print one label for California and one for everywhere else. Even worse to not print it at all and get sued by some greedy law firm.

Ergo you see the warning on everything from faux leather jackets, jewelry, bathing suits, kitty litter to play sand, coffee to prune juice, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18791881
>I have dried ginger and powdered,
Either one of those works too
If you get the fresh root, scrape the skin off with a spoon, cut into thin slices, simmer for 20 min on stove, something like a fat mans thumb size piece per litre of water for a nice strong tea.
For dry ginger same simmering thing but use half the size as you would if it was fresh. For powder you can probably put a teaspoon or so in a measuring cup, add a mug worth of boiling water and then strain into a mug to drink, or just use a teaball or a brew basket or something

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18799392
why are you so stuck on tea being cold brewed? Unlike coffee, heating tea doesn't introduce bitterness, but rather it allows bacteria to be killed. There are known dangers to sun tea for the fact it doesn't get hot enough ti kill bacteria.
Any cold brew shit you are buying labelled as such is INSTANT tea.
At bedtime, nuke a 8 cup/2Qt pyrex measuring cup in your microwave until boiling, pour into a pitcher with 8 teabags, then move to the fridge overnight, adding ice if you wish it not as strong by morning to stop the brew at 5 mins. Use 2-3 large quart teabags like Luzianne or 6-8 small tea bags, maybe even 1 teabag that is flavored, like mint, or orange in spice. I love iced jasmine green tea. Feel free to use loose leaf or bags, whatever.
Matcha is ground tea, and the fame and flavorful foam is just overrated, brew green tea equally, if cost is a concern. I can buy Luzinanne green literally 30 teabags for 1 qt pitchers for like $2 for the whole box. Where do you shop?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18800539
Don't stress anon, yiwu is good stuff. Its not going to have the charcoal roasted flavor that yiwu oolong has but i can see them having some similarities, yiwu puer isn't as punchy and intense as some of the other puer regions, its considered to have a more mellow flavor with enjoyable subtle nuances.
A few comments
Ripes don't benefit from age as much as raws, that said when you get to teas from the early 2000s or older they tend to have different processing from modern ripes, they arent fermented as strongly and they retain more of the character of the tea, those tend to benefit from age more than modern ripes.
2005-2007 was the first puer price bubble, think the dutch tulip craze but with puer. Positives are that there is a lot of affordable puer out there from this time frame, but negatives are that they were pressing any leaves they could get and sometimes quality suffered, i wouldn't sweat it, im not saying the tea you ordered wont be good but its something to be aware of, especially for suspiciously cheap tea from that era.
Anyway it sounds like you picked a decent way to get started, a good variety of ripes should let you get a pretty good idea if you like them and want to explore them further. A raw with some age on it like the 07 you ordered is decent place to start with raws. Young raws are almost a different tea compared to the stuff with a decade or two of age on it, the aged stuff is much smoother, the harsh edges are rounded out some and its starting to devlop "aged tea taste"
Anyway once you get to try your samples make a post about what you like and somone can probably recommended some ideas for what you should explore next.
Cheers

I used to be quite fat. The potato diet as mentioned is solid, but it's not reliant on potatoes at all. Ray Cronise, who originated it only picked potatoes because he knew Penn Jillette liked them. But anything simple, like rice and beans or virtually anything bland will suffice. The goal is to reset taste buds so you're not eating for pleasure, you are eating for survival. It doesn't really matter because it's not meant to be a long term diet. The point is to change your relationship to the food you eat.

That said, I went with what to this day I call the Stalone method. I reme as a fat kid watching some old talk show where they asked him how he was always in such good shape.

He said its easy, if you eat well and exercise 5 days a week, when it comes to the weekend you can do whatever. "Pizza, hamburgers, ice cream... doesn't matter. You've done good it's covered" pretty similar to how the rock now talks about cheat days. It really works though.

And here's a thing, I used to drink Coke like crazy, but on that cut it out other than weekends. The first week was awful and coke on Saturday felt like an amazing relief. The second week it was tasty but I didn't crave it like I one did. The third week I drank it mostly just cause I could. By week 4 I did bother, it seemed gross.

Now I have it on rare occasion and it's an intense treat but that's it.

You have to work with your will power and habits first, anon. No diet trick is going to help because you're trying to build a house by starting from the roof instead of the ground.
I'm not going to send you to the gym or jogg, because this starts with the mind. Set yourself some goals you can achieve. Make your bed everyday when you wake up, even if its annoying. Wash your dishes immediately after eating. Clean that room/garage/backyard that you have been postponing for ages. Sell that extra thing you keep saving in your closet/attic/basement.
Try to get involved with community work, find a new hobbie, try to meet people in events and such.
Good habits work like chain, once you get one the next will follow. If you look forward to do something then you'll want to be at your best, to show your friends and people you care about that you're still made of good stuff, just like them.
Once you finish what you start, and once you get the will to do things that you don't want to do, but you still accomplish them, then you'll have the solid ground to face this with bigger weapons.

Still, it's not only about what you cook. You must understand your metabolism. You are obviously insulin resistant, and yout gut microbiome is also fucked up.
You have to eat more protein and fiber, foods that will saciate you. You say that you always want another dish right? It's not the same to eat a second plate of steak than a second plate of spaghetti. Eat things thats require a lot of chewing, get your jaw exhausted so your hunger becomes something secondary. There is tricks to fill your belly too. Drink a big glass of water before meals. Have some collagen peptide supplements to entertain your stomach with it before meals, it has zero calories and it's healthy. You don't need to starve yourself at the start, you can eat as always and then choose a time (6 pm) to stop eating until next morning. Half fasts are good for this, it will help you control your cravings.

>>18789591
>>18789601
IMO beans matter most, then burrs/grinder and water, then recipe. Also the tasting notes are generally impressions of what the taster was reminded of vs what they directly tasted.

Assuming good beans, water that doesnt suck, and good burrs grinder, you'll have to fix your grind size, and/or water temp and/or pouring technique.

I've been using Hoffmann's 1 Cup v60 method with 50GH/15KH water with the following tweaks for my burrs depending on beans and getting tasting notes very similar to what the roasters listed:

Too acidic / weak = grind finer, increase temp

Too bitter / flavors muddled & undiscernible = grind coarser, agitate less (no swirl / stir / pour closer to coffee bed), lower temp

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18798464
Brush the retained grounds off the outside of the burrs after every use then blow the chaff dust out of the barrel either with your lungs or a air puffer bulb thinger. Fine dust and coffee oils accumulate after several months. You do not need to do this often, but this is when you break it down and clean it with dry paper towels and cotton swabs. Don't use water. Take as little apart as you need to to get in the nooks and crannies. Some grinders are easy to partly or fully reassemble. Other ones are a pain in the ass to put back together because they require resetting the burr sets. Never detach the cone burr from the shaft. Never remove the burr ring from its retainer. There are videos of people breaking down every grinder.

>>18800584
Crushed red pepper hack:
>put some pepper flakes in a jar
>add just enough rice vinegar to re-hydrate the flakes but not make it soupy
>mince, or crush a small clove of garlic with a pinch of salt until nearly a paste
>add the garlic and just enough olive oil to cover the pepper flakes
>mix the ingredients with a fork until the garlic emulsifies the oil and flakes into a thick paste
>store in fridge and use on noodles, rice, etc.

>>18801305
>calories

This is how you spot the goycattle.

1. """Calories""" are a gross over-representation of the chemical energy our bodies can derive from food. Our bodies are not calorimeters, they don't burn food. When you eat food containing "X kcal", you don't actually derive that amount of energy from food, you derive far less. The reason why calorie counting """works""" is because you're massively underfeeding yourself.

2. Moreover, counting calories doesn't actually work even in theory, because the margin of error on caloric content in food that is specified on the label is very high. In some countries it's as high as 20%. This means that you can't even count calories properly, assuming our bodies are perfect calorimeters (they aren't).

3. The CICO concept (more like El Circo lmao) doesn't even work in theory, because the second law of thermodynamics applies ONLY to a closed system - a system that does NOT exchange mass with the environment, it only exchanges energy. The human body is not a thermodynamically closed system, because it constantly exchanges MASS with the environment: sweat, piss, shit - all of this is MASS leaving your body.

4. For the reasons specified above, counting calories is the dumbest shit you can do, because it doesn't even work in theory, let alone in practice. You end up massively underfeeding yourself in any scenario where you count calories with multiple sources of both systematic and random errors. Underfeeding your body leads to a homeostatic response that lowers your basal metabolic rate, so you now need to eat even less food in order to keep losing weight at the same rate which leads you to underfeeding yourself even harder and this CICO circus leads only to one possible outcome - psychological meltdown and binge eating.

The solution? Just eat fatty meat, eggs and fish to satiety lmao. It just werks, because this kind of food rapidly unfucks your satiety signaling caused by years (decades?) of carb addiction.

Make a brine.
>Bring 2 quarts of water to a boil in a 4 quart saucepan
>1 cup of salt
>Small handful of whole black peppercorns
>5 sprigs of thyme
>10 sprigs of parsley
>1 lemon cut in half
>1/4 cup of honey, or sugar
>turn off heat add ice cubes until the saucepan is full making a total of 4 quarts of brine that is now cool enough to use
Brine over night in the fridge 12 hours max. You can re-use the brine a second time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18799449
>what do I marinade these in to be baked in the oven?
I like thighs marinated (overnight) in seasoned greek yogurt, then just move the dish the oven to bake right in the marinade. From inspiration from yogurt II recipe in Ismail Merchant's cookbook passionate meals, I cook grated ginger, grated garlic, cumin in a small saucepan til softened, remove from heat, stir in yogurt when cooled, add garam masala, zest of 1 lemon, juice of 1 lemon, and maybe juz it up a bit more with your preference of more corander, ginger, cayenne, cumin or whatever you like to balance the garam masala, maybe a bit orf cardamom or bay leaf, depending.

That greek yogurt softens the chicken so tenderly, and the garlic and ginger gets deep flavor. Double the marinade for a pourover sauce you can add to your veggies or rice side. garnish with cilantro, or green onions, of couse.

>When was this?
>I used to drink Boags and Cascade all the time as a young fella
Hawke and Keating built a 'sin tax' in the 80's that would stay ahead of CPI inflation. When you buy a bottle of spirits you pay over $90 duties per litre of pure alcohol. Beer is over $55/litre pure IIRC but wine is just taxed at 29% of the wholesale price (because Keating is a cunt and liked to drink wine).
It's why VB about 10 years ago cut their alcohol to 4.6% to keep the price of a slab down, but had to put it back up to 4.9% because people would rather pay an extra 80c a slab for the real thing.
Boags Premium went from a crisp, full-bodied lager at 5% to a skunky watery 4.6% mess to save themselves a few million a year. Used to be one of my favourite beers, now I just drink Boags Draught instead because the price difference isn't worth it.

>>18787219
Here in beautiful Tassie we eat the local wallabies, they taste like kangaroo, only cuter.

The main issue is that our megafauna were wiped out by centuries of firestick farming before they could evolve smaller forms like in many other parts of the world. So the desertification of much of the continent meant few large herbivores. The largest native herbivore by weight IIRC is the dugong. There really wasn't much to base a cuisine on because all you really have is possums, cuscus, dugong, sea turtle, emu and various macropodiae. Seals and muttonbirds are available but severely limited in geography.

As far as edible native plants, apart from macadamias our native plants are difficult to cultivate as their yield per acre is so low. Even when supplied with plenty of water and nutrients they have evolved to fruit only grudgingly and in amounts just necessary for reproduction.

If you're interested there is an excellent book I highly recommend named "One Continuous Picnic: a gastronomic history of Australia" by Symons, which covers how we developed from a precolonial diet to the modern day full of convenience and junk foods without developing the 'peasant' or 'traditional' cuisine culture that anchors all the great cuisines of the world.

https://books.google.com.au/books/about/One_Continuous_Picnic.html?id=_N3qh4chXxwC

>>18787273
>which covers how we developed from a precolonial diet to the modern day full of convenience and junk foods without developing the 'peasant' or 'traditional' cuisine culture that anchors all the great cuisines of the world.
That seems like it's either tailored to the Tasmanian culture, or it's a very naïve point of view.
Millions of migrants from all those countries have shaped Australian food culture for over 100 years, moreso than most other New World nations for various reasons.
Travel through the eastern suburbs of Melbourne by train and you can still see all the backyard vineyards from the Greek and Italian migrants, all still thriving, and I presume many have been adopted by more recent arrivals, opening up even greater culinary options.
There is also the fact that Australia is one of very few nations that can domestically grow tropical and temperate produce without the loss of quality associated with importation.

>>18787373
The book discusses a failure of 'white Australia' to develop a 'traditional' cuisine (which is my point) but this is not the same as importing foreign-born persons and their cuisines (which is also covered by the book).

You also have to bear in mind that Australia was pretty much a closed shop until the 50's when Greeks, Jews and Italians were grudgingly declared culturally compatible with 'white Australia' and allowed in to help rebuild the economy after WW2.

The Tasmanian focus was because Tasmania was (and remains) an agricultural state very close in weather and seasons to Great Britain, and there were a lot of British emigres who wrote extensively about similarities between the two.

I'd encourage you to read the book, if only because it's literally the best book ever published on how Australian food and culture have interacted as society has changed.

I lived through it, and I disagree. Your opinion isn't wrong per se but I feel it allocates blame unevenly.

Labor's dismantling of the Immigration Restriction Act (which was originally intended to protect the Australian working mans' conditions from being degraded by cheap foreign labour) was done at the behest of Trade Unions. Their movement wanted more power and the easiest way was to get import numbers of poor, scared workers with little fallback, few resources and a desperate need for protection. Funnel those workers' votes through that movement to Labor. Libs responded in kind, looking for trad people to offset. It's why Labor imported Leb Muslims and Liberals imported Leb Catholics.

Don't get me wrong, I'm happy with a multiracial society, but multicultural societies are shit. And by culture I'm not talking about food. I'm talking about fundamentally different worldviews that are incompatible, living side-by-side in increasingly more economically stressful circumstances as both parties race to import more and more people that will vote for their side. Our infrastructure is groaning, more and more people rely on government handouts, and fewer people every generation can afford to marry and have a house and a family.

Anyway we're getting off track. I'll just say that I agree with you in principle that both sides of the chamber are responsible for the shitty mess we're in (because so much is clear).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cooking a large amount of bacon all at once can be a bit challenging as it can be difficult to ensure that all of the bacon cooks evenly and thoroughly without becoming burnt or undercooked. One way to cook a large amount of bacon at once would be to use a large baking sheet and place the bacon in a single layer in a preheated oven. This method allows the bacon to cook evenly and makes it easy to flip the bacon to ensure that both sides cook evenly.

Another option would be to use a large skillet or griddle on your stove top, you could cook the bacon in batches, carefully flipping each strip as it cooks to ensure that both sides cook evenly. This method can be a bit more labor intensive but you have more control over the temperature of the skillet/griddle and you can stop the cooking process when the bacon is at your desired level of doneness.

A third option is to use a large outdoor grill, you could use a grilling rack to place the bacon on, this method is great for outdoor cookouts and summer parties, specially with a nice weather.

It is important to note that when cooking such a large amount of bacon it may take a bit longer to cook than the standard stove top methods and you might need to monitor the cooking time more closely to ensure that all of the bacon is cooked through and not burnt. Also it may cause some smoke so make sure you have proper ventilation and keep a fire extinguisher nearby.

And again, this is purely theoretical and you should always be mindful of your own abilities and take safety precautions when cooking and handling large amounts of meat.

posts.com:
>>18797286
If you're interested they're really stupidly easy to make (the ramen eggs).
put the following in a container that will hold about 6 eggs. I use a quart sized deli container.
- 100ml soy sauce
- 100ml mirin
- 500ml water

Now either steam or boil eggs for 6.5 minutes. After the 6.5 minutes you want the cooking process to stop completely so run cold water right into the pot. You can peel the eggs either when still warm or let them cool idk doesn't matter. Anyway put the eggs in the container and let them sit there for at least 2 days in the fridge. Make sure there's something over the eggs to make sure they dont bob out of the water. A paper towel will work, just push it down on top and it's fine. Be delicate tho the eggs are easy to split until they cure. I never have them last that long so I've never eaten one I made over a week ago, but I've heard they should be fine for a couple weeks in the fridge in the brine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18793427
Cook with it you fine gentleman/lady.

I only recently discovered this food "hack" which is actually just wisdom of the impoverished. If you are making some meat and there is fat left over, use it as a substitution the next time a recipe requires "oil" or "butter". You will have saved some money by not having to replenish your oil reserves earlier, AND the flavor profile of the meat will be transferred into whatever you use to cook it with.
You can make like a fried zucchini by just putting (any veg really) directly into the meat fat after removing the meat from the still hot pan.
Add some wine or vinegar (pref balsamic myself) and use a pan safe utensil to scrape at the meat bits in the bottom, it will help flavor the veg while also allowing you to keep the salt content of your dish lower!

(There is sodium in most meat, especially if it was pre-seasoned/marinated, so the sodium will transfer into your second dish cooked in the pan)

I am sharing this with you because I just used some sausage fat in my risotto replacing the butter I would usually use, and OHHHHY boy it's in the top 5 risottos I have ever made.

I was considering trying to cook for a living but afraid it will make me lose a hobby if I had to depend on it to live.

Hope you are well and that this is received well.
Buon' appetito!

You can just use a fine mesh sieve if you don’t care, but it’s good to also use a piece of paper towel or a coffee filter for maximum filtration of fine particles of bacon protein, since the protein can go bad if you leave it too long. That said, it’s kind of like potted beef preservation in that it’s surrounded by fat, so it’s not a huge concern; almost more aesthetic or autistic purity shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Strain bacon fat into a sealable jar until enough is collected
Melt fat and add to boiling water, allow it to mix together
Pour into wide bowl, chill until lard sets firm
Dump water and particles, flip the cake of fat and scrape any leftover bits out
Melt fat into a crockpot or saucepot if you don't have one, put in oven at 220-240F to cook off any excess moisture
(Optionally) Strain this fat through cheesecloth or a rough coffee filter if you observe any additional particles.

Wahlah, you now have relatively pure and refined lard you can use for baking, low temp frying, or sautee. Works as a great replacement for flavoring stir fry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
for beef stock i like to use top round, beef shanks, and beef neck bones. Sometimes only one of those. And when I use top round i take it out before it gets over cooked so i can actually eat it as leftovers another day or something. I like to make sandwiches with top round beef.

Oh and I make vegetable paste/bouillon instead of vegetable stock. instead of boiling veggies in water and draining out the veggies, i use the veggies themselves as the "stock".
I just peel and cut up a whole bunch of my favorite vegetables (onion, carrots, celery, shallot, red bell pepper, parsnip, tomato, ect) cooking them in a covered pot/pan with only a small amount of water on the bottom to jumpstart creating steam on the inside, and i let them cook in the steam created by the vegetables own water until they've all cooked and collapsed being careful to make sure nothing burns on the bottom. Then i keep cooking them uncovered to evaporate more water out of the vegetables until the vegetable mass i started out with shrinks down to like a quarter of what it was. You can mash them, blend them, food process them, or puree them if you want at this stage. All the flavors concentrate and you end up with something that tastes more like sweet candy than vegetables. It's pretty crazy. You can portion and freeze the paste to use in soups and sauces later. They're not as potent and concentrated as store-bought stock bouillon, but they taste better and they still have their fiber with no bullshit ingredients.

Oh you could absolutely get maillard browning while cooking the softened veggies on the stove in the uncovered reducing stage of the recipe. I just tend to avoid this by stirring occasionally because i figure that i can just brown it later when i actually use some of it for something i’m about to eat, but now that I think about it i don’t see any downsides to getting some browning on the veggie paste before putting the paste in storage for later use. And it’s better to brown the vegetables in mush/paste form because then you have access to more surface area to brown, whereas if the vegetables were whole or just cut into pieces only the outside of each piece will get brown.

It’s not a troll post. So you know how sometimes if you cook a large volume of rice, the very bottom of it that touches the base of the pot can sometimes get brown despite the rice being saturated in water? It’s the same mechanism.

Yes at first the vegetables will be saturated in their own water and softening, but then when you get to the part of the recipe where you proceed by cooking and stirring the vegetables uncovered to evaporate their liquid and reduce in volume, you’ll be able to achieve browning.

Is there a secret to making pan sauces feel/taste less oily? I'm getting the flavor balances down pat and I won't stop making them, but it seems like using corn starch always leads to it thickening up mostly well enough, but looking translucent and not all that appealing to others when I offer them pan sauce for their entree or whatever, and it still feels a bit greasy when I eat it myself. Should I go for flour to help with that, or am I just not letting it cook down enough? Do I need to add more water, or even start adding wine?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18798809
You have to be careful with flour in a pan sauce if you don't want it too oily. You have to ensure you degrease very well because flour will bind with fat and then the fat will be in suspension throughout your sauce making it impossible to skim and thus greasy and icky, which is what you were trying to avoid.
Roux typically isn't suited to a pan sauce because you have to skim it for a while after adding so you're looking at a long process.
So make sure you degrease very well, then deglaze with your liquid. If you're using stock you should have it reduced to the consistency you want before adding it so you don't have to spend time waiting for it to reduce.

I'll admit that my OP was just a rehashed reddit comment, but I do appreciate your perspective. Local ag and food systems are the solution to a whole shitload of problems. Supply/demand is a hard construct to unwind with regard to ag and especially animal welfare. If demand is localized and scaled appropriately, quality of life for animals and quality of end food product both improve. I think the issue of veganism is really troubling, because it reflects a natural reaction to a terrible system created by humans (factory food) and a rejection of naturalistic tendencies (most animals eat other animals, and the ones that don't typically get eaten). Human veganism is antithetical to optimized health. But, since we've created a system of animals that are dependent on humans for security and longevity, it seems that a balancing act of ethical breeding practices and maximizing the wellbeing of animals while alive (but ultimately which will either die and feed other animals or can die and feed people) has to occur at some point. But I guess I'm not willing to sacrifice my quality of life and health for the lives or products of other creatures.

If any egg chads are reading this, do yourself a favor. Find that _one_ supplier near your that has the pasture raised chicken eggs from a small farm. Mine is a long-standing booth from the weekly farmers' market. They sell out of eggs for the week between 9 and 10 AM because they're not trying to factory farm them, they're just keeping the chickens they can. It'll take some trying because not all "pasture raised" eggs are created equally. But when you find the good one, you'll know. And it'll drive you crazy, because all it requires to have eggs this good is to care for the chickens like one would a pet, and allow them free time to forage for bugs and stuff. It's insane that such a simple thing is so uncommon now.
A good egg, fresh from a good chicken is unlike what is at the stores. People will go on about yolk color but that will depend only on diet and it can be faked by the industrial farms if they care to do it by feeding the chickens certain nutrients which will make the yolks a darker yellow. A good egg when fresh has a white that will naturally stay around the yolk in the pan. It will be tight and the egg will have some height to it after cooking without you having to push the white towards the yolk. The texture of the white is also way different. It has some texture and it quite opposite of the rubbery that store bought eggs get especially when old. The yolks flavor is noticeably better and it feels just _good_ to eat. Also the shells break cleaner while also being harder.
I pay 5 bucks a dozen and I'll keep doing so until they retire or I die. I could buy 2 dollar dozens from the store but those eggs make me sad. I eat a dozen eggs a week. 3 dollars extra per week is $150 dollars a year and I'll happily pay that for good eggs every single day of my life until I can get chickens of my own.

The name "Just Egg" is a branding choice by the company that produces it and it is not intended to deceive or mislead consumers. The name is meant to convey the idea that it is an egg substitute that is plant-based, and it allows consumers to quickly identify it as a vegan or plant-based alternative to traditional eggs.

As you pointed out, "Just" can mean "only" or "solely" and in this case, the "Just" in "Just Egg" doesn't mean that the product contains only eggs, but it's just an egg substitute. It's a simple way for the brand to create a name that makes it easy for customers to understand that it's an egg substitute and it's plant-based, even if it doesn't contain real eggs.

In general, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) regulates food labeling and advertising in the United States to make sure that they don't mislead consumers. So it's important to understand that products are often labeled in a way that makes it easy for consumers to identify what they are buying and that they meet the criteria set by these regulatory agencies.

Has anyone in this board grown culinary mushrooms for eating? This is food but I've never seen a thread about it. Let me introduce you guys to the fun of growing mushrooms. It's so easy and this hobby can provide hours of active entertainment.

To start with, I had the idea to try growing oyster mushrooms that I got from the grocery store. These cost about $15/lb here which is quite a scam considering they can be cloned by an average retard. So check this out, all you have to do is take out little bits from the mushrooms with a scalpel and feed them. Then they'll grow into a new organism. I will give more details in subsequent posts.

>>18768748
So what you're seeing in these images is little bits of flesh that I extracted from inside the fleshiest part of the mushroom. The secret that Big Mushroom doesn't want you to know is that you have to do all this in an extremely clean environment. Mushrooms are a fungus, and so is mold, which means that in order to grow mushrooms you need to essentially prepare a perfect environment for mold to grow, but without growing mold. The only way to do this is by physically preventing a single mold spore to come in. So when you open up the mushrooms, do so by ripping them, and then use a flame -sterilized scalpel to carefully get out a piece of flesh. All of this needs to be done inside a still air box, which can be made by overturning a large plastic tote and cutting two armholes so you can do mushroom stuff inside it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768775
The medium that I have placed the flesh on is malt extract agar. This is essentially a nutrient-rich jelly which is used to fill petri dishes, which is normally used to cultivate funguses and bacteria in a lab environment. I am using small plastic ketchup containers instead of real petri dishes because I'm poor. In order to make these things, you need a few powder ingredients (the nutrients and the agar) and then you mix it with water and pressure cook it for 45 minutes to make sure there isn't a single living organism or spore in the mixture. Then pour it into ketchup containers (inside the still air box) while it's still hot, and let it cool, and it becomes a nutritious and delicious and sterile medium on which you can propagate mushroom clones.

In the last couple images, and this one, you can see how the mushroom flesh sends out fibers to colonize and eat the agar jelly. It's so beautiful to watch this. The purpose of the jelly step is to make sure that our cultures do not have any contaminants in them. Like I was saying before, this entire game is basically about getting a clean culture which doesn't have any bacteria or mold. The original mushrooms were in the grocery store for God knows how long, getting sneezed on and poked by gross children and bugs, and are covered in contamination. I lost three of five of the original agar cups to bacteria. But you can clone the fuzz from these cups by cutting out a clean and healthy piece and transferring it to a fresh cup. And basically, you can keep doing this indefinitely to make as much as you want, until your cultures are 100% clean.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18768834
Quick background on mushroom biology: mushrooms aren't plants. They are more closely related to humans than they are to plants. Basically, the entire organism is a big fluffy network called the mycelium, which in the wild, lives normally underground or inside trees. And it eats food like animals. The mushroom itself, which you eat, is basically just a sex organ of the mycelium. It sprouts forth from the soil or out the side of a tree to release spores in very certain conditions. But 99% of the organism is this white fluff which is hidden from view.

So what you can do is provoke a bit of a mushroom to grow more of this fluff, which I've just shown you how to do. Then you can feed it until it becomes big, which I'm going to show you how to do next.

Mycelium loves to eat whole grains, so after you have got some clean cuttings isolated on agar, then you're gonna want to multiply it faster by feeding it some grains. Popular and cheap choices include wild birdseed, whole oats, popcorn kernels, and brown rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768876
What you do to make the jars is: soak your grains of choice in water overnight until they're nice and saturated. Then strain, then dump them out onto a few baking sheets and let them dry off until they're dry on the outside. You want the grains to be fully wet on the inside (full of water) but not actually be wet on the outside, so they're just at maximum internal water capacity. That's the perfect hydration level. Then put the grains inside some jars and pressure cook them at 15psi for 90 minutes to kill all the mold and bacteria inside the jars. Then you will have some jars of mushroom food which your mycelium will love to eat.

After the jars are cool, bring them into your still air box and put the mycelium from the jelly cups inside. Cut the jelly into little squares with a flame-sterilized scalpel before you dump them in. Then give it a good shake so the mycelium gets spread around in the grains. This will help it colonize faster.

This is what my jars looked like after a day of the mycelium spreading around the grains.

The final stage is that the colonized grain spawn will be used to incubate these giant bags, which contain a mixture of 50% hickory sawdust and 50% soy hulls. Each jar can colonize like 12 of these bags.

If you guys are interested in this hobby, don't fall for the "kits". You can buy "mushroom grow kits" on the internet which basically come with a small pre-sterilized bag of substrate, and a syringe of liquid mycelium culture for you to inject in there. These things are basically a fun toy or an interesting gift for someone in the office, but they're not close to efficient compared to doing everything yourself. I can make these large 5lb fruiting blocks for about $1.50 each, which will be largely converted into mushroom, whereas the grow kits are basically more expensive than just buying mushrooms at the store. posts.com:
>>18769096
Just reread my own ramblings and I could've elaborate more on the final step. When you're making your fruiting blocks, the best source for sawdust is hardwood pellets used for pellet grills and smokers. You can buy hickory pellets at Lowes for 37 cents a pound. Soy hulls are an agricultural waste product and you can buy it online for even cheaper than that. I think they're normally used to feed pigs. The best recipe for bulk substrate for woodloving mushrooms, which includes oysters and shiitake, is 1 part sawdust, 1 part soy hulls, and 3 parts water, all by weight.

There are some alternative substrates which you can use to varying degrees of success. Oysters can also be grown on a mixture of straw and coffee grounds. Or just sawdust, or just straw.

You also don't need to use these bags, obviously, you can use any container. But these are cheap, large, and transparent. And they're safe to pressure cook, which you'll need to do depending on how nutritious your substrate is. If you're just using pure straw, you can just soak it in water and put it right in the bags, and then dump the grain spawn on top and shake it up. Mushroom mycelium has its own immune system, as it's a complex living organism after all, so it's naturally pretty resistant to mold and bacteria once it's established. You can expose a fully colonized jar to the open air, or dump it in a bag of straw, and it will be fine. But soy hulls and coffee grounds are extremely nutritional and encourage the growth of competitive mold. So with these more effective substrates, you need to pressure cook them just like you did the grain jars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18769113
There's outdoor cultivation methods which mimic the natural environment much more closely. If you grow mushrooms outside it's pretty similar to composting and you don't need to sterilize anything. However, whether you can do this depends largely on your local climate and what you want to grow. And it's also pretty much a crapshoot and less controlled than what I'm doing here. Like you can get some mushrooms from the grocery store and shred them up, throw them on the ground in your backyard, and cover it with a pile of hardwood chips and sawdust and coffee grounds, and your weather and local humidity is right, then mushrooms are probably gonna grow out of it. But it might be multiple years before you see anything and you won't have huge yield, and you might accidentally grow some other shit you didn't want. Most people in this hobby throw their spent substrate in a pile in the backyard and extra mushrooms keep randomly growing out for many years. But that's only worth it because you might as well do it, I wouldn't rely on that as a reliable farming method.

Another cool thing you can do is to inoculate an entire log with spores or liquid culture from a log colonizing species. I have seen it done where someone gets a whole log, then drills a few holes in it and inseminates the log with mycelium, then plugs the holes and wait for mushrooms to start popping out of the log. On Paul Stamets website he sells mushroom plugs that you can stick right into a log for this purpose. However I've never done this so I can't speak in depth about it.

It's incredibly fucking cheap once you get everything running. A really easy process would be
1) Buy approx 1Kg of grain spawn of oyster mushroom mycelium
2) Use 100g and grow 10kg of cloned grain spawn
3) Now you got enough grain spawn (if healthy) to inoculate a shitton of substrate
4) Substrate can be something as cheap as sawdust or coconut fiber if you're in a tropical country
5) Profit????
Most of your costs will be in the initial stage while setting everything up and when you inevitably fuck up. But it's a really fun process and if you succeed you can feel good about yourself for turning trash into food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18777386
It depends on the genetics as well as how even your sub is. If it's lumpy or uneven, or the casing layer is not the same thickness all over, you're more likely to get fewer larger mushrooms rather than an even canopy of smaller ones. It's just because if a handful of pins form before the other ones, then they're going to get more nutrients and water and the later pins will get less, or won't even bother forming at all.

You can get preposterously huge mushrooms if you cover most of the sub with a garbage bag or something and just cut a small hole where light and fresh air can contact the sub. Basically just forcing an entire tub to only fruit in one small location. It'll put all its nutrients and water into the one mushroom and it'll be gigantic.

But for the record I'm talking about culinary mushrooms. This is a blue board so don't get my thread deleted please.

>>18777451
Yes, that's another species that grows on hardwood. Everything I've posted will theoretically directly apply to those also. Though i have no idea what temperature they like or how long it takes. Basically anything that grows on a tree, you can grow it in a bag of sawdust

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18777785
For a dung-loving and top-fruiting culinary mushroom such as white buttons:

Verm is not a critical component of the substrate in any capacity, but it helps the mycelial network grow by making the sub more airy. It doesn't contain any nutrients. You should use verm mixed with coco coir as the bulk sub. Mix this mixture with the grains to form most of the substrate. And then top it with a layer of just verm+coir about half an inch thick. This helps it retain moisture, protects the grains from contaminants, and makes it fruit more evenly.

>Also, how much do you make annually from this venture and where do you live?
It's my first year, started last February so it's hard to give you an annual estimate. At the markets we'd make about $2-300/market, maybe net $200 average after booth fee and packaging costs. Variety is key for booth appeal and sales of course. But we started talking to some local farms and it's surprising how many either don't grow their own at all, or just buy blocks. We do 300 blocks a week right now, with one client. Originally they wanted 600 but I wasn't sure I had the capital available to retool to meet that, so went with a more conservative number to start. My own farm projects to fruit another 300 blocks per week May-October, so we're looking at at least 900 blocks/week pretty soon. At 300 blocks / week we net $1200 / week. We hope to offer some consulting this summer to build more customers, as well as cold calling. Just hope we can handle the volume.

I live a little bit west of Portland, OR and have been growing for about ten years, but more in the last 3 than all the years prior combined, naturally.

Yeah I love mushrooms, but for me they're kinda seasonal because my favorites are all wild. Portobellos are expensive for what you get and button mushrooms are okay but mostly I'd rather just wait.

It is notable there is little evidence of them causing issues despite how much those kinds of mushrooms are consumed. That it's a big secret being kept under wraps by mushroom growers still sounds suspicious though. The toxicity of so many other substances is well known and it goes into food advisories. Hell, licorice is straight up poisonous and can kill you if you eat too much, any kind of barbecue laces the food with chemicals toxic to the body, people just ignore it because it's also what makes it so tasty.

So the notion that button mushrooms and portobello are secretly toxic and giving people cancer but it's all being kept under wraps by the powerful mushroom mafia doesn't quite add up.

Also, I used to work for a small fancy food store in my area and the mushrooms they sold are from a local farm. They mostly grow the buttons and portobellos, but also grow shitake, oyster, king oyster and a couple others. One would think that if any mushroom growers knew of this and it was true, they would market and sell other mushrooms on that basis, as mushrooms that are totally safe. You can day, ohh but the mushroom mafia won't like that, but are they going to try and murder a whole company of people?

Do get me wrong, I am not meaning to discount any potential danger. But the one dude who seems to be yelling the loudest that conventional mushrooms will give you cancer is the same guy trying to sell you kits to grow other kinds of mushrooms. That's fishy, no two ways about it.

It has me intrigued though and as a mushroom lover I'm going to keep my eye on it. The world these days is super weird, sifting real information from noise gets harder every day.

Semi related to this thread, but do any of you mushroom guys know anything about yeast extract specifically using autolysis? I'm trying to make homemade marmite, but there's next to no reliable information on the web to do it properly and consistently.

Ragusea made an attempt at it, but he quickly gave up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The method with the lowest barrier for entry is the Uncle Ben's Tek. Get your spore syringe and 20 bags of Uncle Ben's brown rice. Use a still air box and a small alcohol stove so you can sterilize the syringe between inoculations. After the rice has colonized you can fruit right off the cakes or spawn to bulk.
You don't have to use uncle ben's, any unflavored ready brown rice works. This method is useful because you don't have to have great sterile procedures or a pressure cooker to sterilize grains. Ready rice is already sterile as it must be shelf stable. It also gives you the option to either fruit directly, or use the colonized cakes to spawn to bulk for higher yields.

>>18795874
A $1k rice cooker is not necessary, but absolutely fantastic if you love rice.

Anova precision oven is not necessary, but the size is actually really great. Bigger than a toaster oven, but a lot smaller than an oven. I use it for a lot more than my old toaster oven and my oven.

Sous vide. Meats on easy mode. If you're cooking a lotta of burgers, steaks, etc it is a god send for consistent and delicious output. Boiling in a plastic bag meme activate.

Microwave don't have an never will. The anova oven works 10000x better albeit much slower.

Air fryer. Only good if you like crispy things and eat a lot of frozen food. NOT the same as a convection oven.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18796416
The automated pressure cooking works excellently with my foodi.

I have yet to make any bread with my apo, but I can tell at 100% steam it would do good things with steamed buns. I've been doing a lot of experimenting with cooking meats.

The really fun part about the apo is that it is a very novel way to cook food, so you can really let your imagination run wild with experimentation.

For example
I set it at 185ish and 100% steam for perfectly cooked potatoes, but I used a silicon "bowl" and had the potatoes submerged in heavy cream, butter, cheese, and bacon. After maybe 2 hours I used my food mill to turn the entire thing into mashed potatoes. Superbly delicious.

48hr meats with 100% steam also works amazing.

>>18796883
The zoji you want depends on how much you love short grain rice and how much you're willing to spend. A pressure + induction cooker makes remarkably delicious short grain rice. If you eat rice 3-5 days a week getting the 500 dollar induction+pressure model will make you be a worthwhile purchase. If you cook mainly long grain getting the base 150 dollar model is more than enough for excellent rice.

The flame dance model has a "burnt bottom" setting that perfectly crisps the rice for claypot style bowls. :D Incredibly delicious.

The burnt bottom setting has gone to near blackened rice, but it has never tasted burnt. It's incredible what the Japs have done with their love of rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18795889
I get really upset when a person calls an immersion circulator a sous vide. Let's review...
>Immersion circulator - an instrument designed to circulate a liquid such as water while heating said liquid to a precise temperature determined by the user. Circulation of the liquid ensures consistent distribution of heat throughout its volume
>Sous vide - a method, interpreted as "under vaccuum" in French, that involves vaccuum sealing foodstuffs within plastic envelopes with the intent to cook them in a liquid bath, usually with the aid of an immersion circulator
>Water oven - an apparatus for cooking that combines an immersion circulator with a volume of water to acheive a temperature stable environment in which foods can be heated to a consistent temperature for a given length of time
When immersion circulators first came onto the scene, adventurous chefs were doing cool things with them. Now, a victim of its own success, the circulator is inseparable from sous vide cooking and "muh perfect well done steak". This isn't just autism. These words have meanings apart from each other. Vaccum sealing is useful, even without cooking via circulator (e.g. marinating meats or compressing fruit). Circulators can work their magic without plastic bags (e.g. coaxing unique textures from eggs or hot water bath for making yogurt in jars). The possibilities are vast. It's not just a steak machine.

posts.com: Old Fashioned learning update on posts last month: tonight I realized the importance of having adequate citrus, or at least not using shitty or old citrus in your cocktails. I'm working with Manhattans now and I was confused at why they were turning out so fucking bitter, but then realized it was a mix of either not thoroughly rinsing glasses (it's my own glass, same drink bases, so what's the big deal? the oils stay in!), having old citrus to peel (the oranges were bought on discount and have been in the fridge for over a month I think?), and reusing peels between drinks hours apart (again, it's my own drink, my own glass, and I'm experimenting on low alcohol volumes, so I figured what was the big fucking deal?). Some combination of the three -- probably the reusing of the old peels especially -- resulted in extremely bitter Manhattans. Using a fresh peel (of the same old oranges in just a rinsed glass) with a reposado tequila manhattan (Blue Nectar rep, M&R rosso, Peychaud's) had much much better results. I'm still not achieving the balance I want with these cocktails, but at least I'm finally not taking steps backwards.

If you want an all-round substitute for any type of cocktail mix, you probably want to start with a reposado. From what I've read the best intro reposado buy on all counts (accessibility, cost, etc) is probably Espolon, but with tequila there's a lot of great brands and a lot of personal taste involved. With any new liquor, look for tastings in your area and go -- even if they cost some $50 at the door, IT'S ALWAYS WORTH IT (not for wine or beer where there's a ton of free tastings however).

Adding to Bon Appetit's list, there are agave spirits in general including mezcals (of which tequila is of course a subtype), but don't dive into all this right away unless you live in Mexico or near the border and can access good bottles on the cheap. There are also non-100% agave spirits (mixtos), which should always be avoided in the U.S., but can again be fair game to explore in Mexico.

Unaged is cheaper, extra aged is more expensive, just like with any other liquor. Unaged can be just as good to sip as extra aged, just like any other liquor. Do some background research on general reviews from people in the know (liquor.com has nice intro best-of lists), but don't read more than you drink, just like any other liquor.

Sourdough refers to using natural yeast from the air for rising, rather than dried/fresh store bought stuff. Not sure where the salt comes into it other than stopping the yeast going out of control.
I assume any oven type is useable aslong as it gets hot enough. I bake at 220c for 30-40 minutes for a full sized (800g~) loaf.
If you over proof dough before baking the structure will collapse in the oven and youll get a flat loaf.

>>18787797
How stupid and thoughtless of you to ask such mundane questions the lowest of slime could answer with their own meager intellect.

A great rice cooker makes rice better, more consistently, and more conveniently than cooking it in a pot ever could.

Here is my recipe for perfect rice. It is the best, most detailed recipe for cooking the best rice in a pot on the stove. Period.

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

My high end rice cooker does a better job than that recipe does in less time and no fiddle fucking around. My cheaper rice cooker did not do a better job than my pot recipe.

It probably does. I honestly haven't spent the time testing it on lower grade rice.

My advice would be to watch the soak time carefully. It may only need 10-15 minutes. The breaking/crumble test should still apply.

You also don't need to wash medium/long grain rice as much for very high quality results. It's extremely important for short grain because it makes each grain of rice feel smooth as you chew it. Long grain rice naturally has a rougher texture to it.

I've shared my recipe quite a few times on here, but haven't heard anyone report back with results. I'd appreciate the effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18800830
You wash short grain because it improves the texture of the rice granules. When you wash/polish the rice it has a satisfying smooth feeling. Unwashed has a rough texture that is not as nice imo.

I found that washing also gave the rice a cleaner flavor as well. This is a much subtler difference than the smooth vs rough thing.

I made 2 exactly similar batches of rice in my rice cooker. One was washed thoroughly the other wasn't. Interesting test.

And yeah... my recipe is for short grain rice, and I guarantee you it does it better than your recipe 1 and 4. Try it if you don't believe me.

>Noma, one of the most feted restaurants in the world, is set to close its doors to diners next year. SInce opening two decades ago, the Copenhagen restaurant -- credited with the invention of New Nordic Cuisine -- topped the list of the World's 50 Best Restaurants five times, most recently in 2021.

>But after years of serving dishes based on locally foraged ingredients -- from reindeer brain custard with bee pollen to a quince and fermented rice ice cream with an oyster caramel -- chef René Redzepi's three-Michelin-star venture will bring its restaurant chapter to a close at the end of 2024. The following year it will be reborn as a "giant lab," dubbed Noma 3.0. "(It will be) a pioneering test kitchen dedicated to the work of food innovation and the development of new flavors, one that will share the fruits of our efforts more widely than ever before," the restaurant said in a statement on its website.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18788379
Half-true. Alcohol has been a staple of humanity for a very long time, however wine and beer we're naturally very low in alcohol content compared to their modern day counterparts. Beer in the middle ages would be somewhere between 2-3% alcohol and wine under 10%. Likewise, distilled alcohol is a very recent development from a human history stand point and contains way more alcohol than any of our ancestors would ever be drinking in one sitting. Also alcohol has been with humans for thousands of years in a strictly social and communal setting, again it's only recently (last 300 years or so) that humanity has had the capability to just have personal bottles of highly alcoholic spirits just sitting at home, available to drink by yourself whenever you want.
Tldr; yes, humanity has used alcohol for thousands of years but we use it vastly different than our ancestors

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18792410
>stimulate your gratification receptors
Alcohol addiction is more insidious. There is the dopamine receptor burnout you're talking about, but there's also the GABA burnout. The brain cannot downregulate its functions because it stopped producing GABA, since alcohol stimulates the receptors. This is why cold-turkey in heavy alcoholics causes shit like hallucinations, heart symptoms or seizures. If you don't get DTs you still suffer the consequences like emotional instability, anxiety, heart palpitations, etc. Alcohol dependence is much worse than just burning out your coom receptors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You can't make baked "fries" no. But you can make really amazing roast potatoes that are IMO even better than fries.

-peel and cut into wedges
-set a pot of water with a tsp of baking soda
-par boil the potatoes until you can just barely pierce them with a paring knife, then drain
-rough up the drained potatoes by giving them a couple of shakes in the pot. The goal here is to get the edges and corners just slightly smashed because that bit of crushed exterior is what is going to crisp up in the oven. If you over cooked the potato during the par boil step then you wind up with mashed potato here which is not what you want
-lay the potatoes out in a single layer on a sheet pan and coat them in oil, a lot of oil, every square inch needs to be lubed up in order to go golden brown and crispy in the oven
-bake at 350 for 45min to 1 hour depending on how thick you cut the wedges. Flip once after 30 minutes for even browning.
-the goal is to get them super crisp all over so you are going to bake them for way longer than you think you need to, the wedges will shrink by about half size during the bake
-the result is crispy, golden roast potatoes, the best potato wedges you've ever eaten I guarantee it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yeah, parboil and use a ton of fat, beef suet for example. It also helps if you take the time to fiddle about turning and moving all of them to get even crisping. I don't know if it's worth the effort, I'd second just doing good roast potatoes.

it's nearly impossible to make french fries style potatoes without deep frying them.
frozen pre-fried fries cooked in an air fryer is the closest you can get, but they still taste pretty dry.
just accept this and try making really good oven roasted potatoes instead:
-cut them into bigger chunks
-boil in salted water for 10 minutes
-drain and let it rest, ideally on a rack or even in the fridge
-toss the pieces in a bowl and coat them with oil
-cook the potatoes in a hot oven until golden brown, stirring every 10 minutes or so

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I was younger I recoiled at the idea of a fish sandwich from McDonald's but I still remember the first time I had it circa 2002 on a Friday when I decided to throw caution in the wind and get the Filet-O-Fish McDeal. Was it life changing? I wouldn't go quite this far but it certainly was an eye opener.

No, it might not be my usual or even a frequent companion in my car, but the Filet-O-Fish holds a special place in my heart. The soft steamed bun is like a heavenly pillow that holds a perfectly crisp and flaky patty of sustainable Alaskan pollock. The tartar sauce is impeccable with just the right amount of tanginess and the perfect creamy companion to the patty; it really does tie everything together. Cheese on fish? I wasn't a believer either but that slice of processed cheddar cheese, invariably perfectly melted like you see in the ads, is a magnificient addition. Possibly superfluous, I can't say for sure because I've only had one with cheese, but I have faith that the McDonald's creators knew what they were doing when they added it; they tend to perceive the gestalt of each menu item in a way that most of us simply cannot.

I am a fan of juxtaposing textures and I concede that the Filet-O-Fish does not have a contrasting crunch to balance the impossibly soft steamed bun and generous helping of tartar sauce. But you know what? It works. God knows why but it works, it really does. I sometimes alternate bites with their world famous fries, refreshing every so often with an ice cold Diet Coke that cleanses my palate and readies me for the next delightful bite.

For me, it will always be the McChicken. But when I'm feeling adventuresome or just want a change from the usual perfect sandwich, I go for the Filet-O-Fish.

>>18799409
I mix it with softened cream cheese, chives and a little "crab salt" (idk wtf it's made of, but it's good af) as a sandwich spread. It's also nice as a filling for cannelloni or large pasta shells, especially if you swap the cream cheese for ricotta. If made this way, I like a chunky tomato sauce, for it. Just garlic, olive oil, hand-crushed tomatoes, tomato juice and more sweet parsley than you think you'd need. Arrange the cooked-and-stuffed cannelloni in a baking dish, top with the freshly made sauce and bake to heat through.

There's also the obvious options of crabcakes, crab salad and crab chowder.

I've only used the gigantic tins that are sold in the refrigerated seafood section of most supermarkets for any of these dishes so if you're using shelf stable tinned crab, YMMV.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
cut it into squares.
You want to get the water out of it so it can be cooked without being a weird soggy mess. Best way to do this is actually to boil it in salted water like pasta for 5-10m and then lay out to dry completely ideally. Pressing it is a meme, no restaurant on the planet does that because it's stupid.
Now that it's dry toss it in a mixture of corn starch with equal part flour and salt / pepper. You could probably add other seasonings if you want. Now you can either fry it or bake it. I usually bake it because then I can walk away and come back later. If frying use a good amount of oil. More than you would think probably, but not deep fry. You want the oil to come up the squares a bit. Get all sides light brown and ur done.
If baking I also put in slightly smaller squares of sweet potato tossed in cornstarch as well. This is the secret to getting that crispy outside edge on sweet potatoes. Toss the tofu and sweet potatoes in some oil and bake 400F until brown enough for you. For me that's about 20 minutes and I give it a good stir after about 15m.
One of my weekly meals is baked tofu and sweet potatoes like this with a basic peanut sauce on rice. Btw for an oil I like coconut oil for this but if you do that you'd have to melt the oil before you toss everything in oil. For me that's easy because I'm using a cast iron to bake it all in anyway so I just melt the oil in that. Go ahead and use your sneed oil here if that's your thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18788555
>you need to know all the tips and tricks
Being a good cook isn't about tips or tricks.
It's about being able to eyeball seasonings, knowing what goes with what, timing, surface to volume ratios, salt vs moisture levels, getting the right equipment, knowing the taste of those you're cooking for, etc.

You can go download a million meatloaf recipes, and you might even like most of them, but only practice will let you riff something up with what you have on hand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18788555
First take a good meat. Pork/beef combination or just beef. Around 30% of fat content total. It should be really cold.
Grind it. Cool it down again because grinder will heat it up. Mix it really, really well and never allow its temperature rise higher than +11 Celsius. You can add 10% of meat weight of icy cold water if you want. Takes around 5 minutes of mixing. You'll know it's mixed well when it almost doesn't stick to the bowl anymore and stays in one piece. When you move your fingers apart you'll see long strings of mince. Add salt, around 1-2% of meat weight (depends on your taste really). Sometimes it just doesn't mix like that which means either temperature was fucked up or meat wasn't aged at least for 3-4 days or started to rot.
Put it in your baking form. Set temperature in the oven around 90 Celsius. Add few trays with water into the oven to raise humidity. Put thermometer into the center of the loaf and bake until 70 celsius reached. Cool it down. Enjoy.

I've been with my wife for 10 years now. We met in high school, and I got her pregnant.

We'd get into screaming arguments constantly about how lazy and worthless she was. I felt like an asshole for it, but goddamn she was a real piece of work. The only reason I dealt with all this was for the kids, and also because the sex is great.

But one night, I got fed up. Not only did she get drunk, neglect the kids, and made me top Ramen for dinner, but she decided to give me attitude too. She was being real fucking bitchy. So I told my grandparents to keep an eye on the kids and told my wife we were going to go out and have dinner together. I drove maybe 3 blocks to a quiet area (we live in Oregon, it's not hard to find a quiet field) and I got out of the car, went around like I was going to open her door for her and let her out, and I just beat the shit out of her while she was still seatbelted. After a few punches, I asked her if she wanted to go back to her parents. She started screaming and yelling and said yes, so I beat the shit out of her again. Then I asked her what she wanted to do. She finally got smart and said she wanted to go home. So I took her home and dared her to start trouble. I even handed her my cellphone and dialed her mom's number on the drive home. I made her talk to her mom, while daring her to fucking say something.

Before that incident, I had never laid a hand on her. But I had always threatened it. I told her "one of these days, if you don't straighten up, I'm going to lay hands on you."

All my meals have been on time, and she just recently tried to make a meatloaf. It was mediocre, but I was just thrilled that she tried.
Do with this information what you will.
